key_points: President-elect Joe Biden's inauguration features scaled-back, heavily virtual ceremonies due to COVID-19 and security concerns.
More than 25,000 National Guard soldiers are deployed in Washington, D.C., for security following the January 6th insurrection.
A star-studded virtual concert hosted by Tom Hanks will replace the traditional black-tie inaugural balls.
A memorial for coronavirus victims and several days of virtual programming precede the inauguration.
Security concerns prompted changes to Biden's travel plans and the postponement of the inauguration rehearsal.
The National Mall is closed, and crowd size at the inauguration will be significantly reduced, with about 1,000 guests expected.
Former Presidents Obama, Bush, and Clinton, along with former First Ladies, will attend; former President Trump will not.
Post-inauguration events include a Pass in Review, a visit to Arlington National Cemetery, and a virtual parade.
Lady Gaga will sing the National Anthem, and Jennifer Lopez will perform at the ceremony.
'Celebrating America' TV special will feature performances and remarks from Biden and Harris, replacing in-person balls.
